DOC.HEAD: AT&T Gets Transportation Department Computer Contract
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Aviation Administration has awarded a contract potentially worth $853 million to a unit of American Telephone & Telegraph Co. for up to 40,000 computer workstations at Transportation Department offices around the country, officials said. AT&T Computer Systems announced Thursday it had won the ``networked computing contract,'' which will provide computer hardware, software, training and maintenance for FAA and other government transportation offices. Initial value of the three-year contract is $18.8 million, but both government and company officials said it could reach $853 million with five one-year options to install a network of computers in all department regional, branch and local offices. The department now uses ``a hodgepodge'' of 56 brands of microcomputers, several incompatable software programs and a variety of local area computer networks, said FAA spokesman John Leyden. He said the new contract covers desk, laptop and other computers in a network for administrative offices and is not part of plans to upgrade FAA air traffic control operations. Leyden said it was the biggest contract FAA has awarded. He said about $534 million worth of equipment and work would be for FAA offices and the rest for other Transportation offices. The system to be installed is called OATS, for Office Automation Technology and Service. ``We believe this is one of the largest desktop office automation contracts ever awarded, '' said Gordon J. Bridge, president of AT&T Computer Systems. He said it represents a major milestone in AT&T's computer company, which is six years old. He said the new system will save the government money by increasing productivity with state-of-the-art computers and software.
